77066360.review: A game that truly blends the boundary between Disilliusions, manga, and horror. The story is not dissimilar to the depth you would see in projects like Amnesia or The Evil Within, but DMH brings the thunder by mixing manga and horror in a big vat of disillusions. The story follows Dis, a short offhand form of the word Disillusion, both bringing back the thematic elements of the game, as well as creating a truly enjoyable main protagonist along the same levels of Steins Gate, Danganronpa V3, and Invasion of the Booby Snatchers. A true revival of the genre, basically The Birth of a Nation if it was a horror game about Manga and Disillusions. I should mention if you like Manga and Horror and Disillusions, this game is particularly down your bowling alley. Anyways, this game reminds me of the time I went over to my pal Mark's place, he was throwing a Halloween party, but he was too busy yartzing in the bathroom because he tried to mix candy corn with gin. So I schmoove my way over to his girlfriend and try to put the moves on her, but it doesn't work so I kicked through the second story hallway window and shred my leg on broken glass and had to go to the hospital for lacerations in a main artery. Anyway, the game's a solid 7/10

72792585.review:
At first, I saw this game in a video by the german youtuber "Corrupted" in his video "SCHLECHTE HORROR GAMES #22" (Bad Horror Games #22).
I gifted this game to my friend and he gifted me it back. Epico.

Now for the review:
DMH feels more like a joke project or the first game of a new game developer. Despite that, the game gave me a good chuckle with the translation and the "voice acting" which ruined the atmoshpere a little.
Story: (Lvl 1-3)
We are playing as Dis, who has gotten an invite by his friend Vigil to visit him in an abandoned, small and old house, inhabitated by mannequinns. After exploring the 1st & 2nd level of the game, we find out that Vigil is that end he got killed, with bombs (Cause of death still unclear). In the 3rd level we play as the policewoman Sui, which investigates an insland on which people died. At the end we find out, that Sui is all behind this and Vigil did nothing.
Now, the concept of the story it self isnt that bad, but its not believable. It doesnt convince that much.

Graphics:
The graphics arent surely a masterpiece, but also not bad. For a 1€ game, what do you expect? The game didnt look blurry or pixeled. So its fine to me. The artstyle of the characters... well, its manga I guess?

Gameplay: 
In the game you walk around a map and trigger certain events which are marked with "???".
Here is a good example of the japanese horror mannequine cliché. I am not saying, its bad that is has been used here (even though it was quite a lot) and I wouldnt think of something else, with which you could replace the mannequins. One of the annoying things, is that the camera swings to the happening, not allowing the player to act like he wants. I am sure that it would be more scarier if the player would turn around and the mannequin would stand behind him instead of "Camera goes WEEEE". The only things that shocked me, were the jumpscares, but they were even predicitable, so it wasnt that bad.

Sound:
Not gonna lie, its not that bad. But the sound which gets played when you see a mannequinn flying around reminds me of the sound effect which you see in 21st century humor videos.

Overall:
If there would have been more effort put in, the game might get good. Its hard to rate this game, since it has something on it, which makes it good. I dont wanna be to harsh. I give this game, a 5/10

34381255.review:
Tags: Adventure - WS - Walking Simulator
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Unity engine corridor walker with mediocre and few jump scares and slow walk speed. 

Bunch of interactable hotspots that float around and that you can see through walls. Activate them all to finish a chapter. Chapters would be insanely short so they severely armstrung the walking speed to try to pad things up. The spookies here are just aggresively low budget, some of them dont fire correctly or when you are facing the right way and it seems like the dev throws less and less of them at you as if he got lazy or embarassed. Usually progression through level is funnelled through a chokehold in the form of a keyhunt to activate certain key scripts. Can mean annoying backtracking and getting stonewalled. The dialogue feels a little robotic and are often comments on the poor level design (e.g. As expected there are trashcans blocking this way through I will have to go another way). I found the environments laborious to get through and unfulfilling to explore. The quality of the art was low to mediocre and there were very precious few effort wasted on that either. Finished chapter 1, got stuck near the end of chapter 2 and gave up on chapter 3 and feel like I've seen most of the game in about an hour. Removed for declutter.

29527575.review:
A short little thing to kill some time.

Despite the title says horror, rather think of it as a creepier kind of Scooby Doo tale. Sure there are some jump scares and playing it alone in the dark (no pun intended) could be disturbing, you won't really get nightmares. And that's not a really bad thing either.

Pros
- Creepy start.
- Short. Yes, it's usually a con, but this game doesn't take too much of your life.
- Sui is quite a mouth-watering treat. Yes, she is a cop, but no cop wears a uniform like this. Not even a porn actress if tries acting like a cop.
- Has multiplayer. Well, it's a good thing, isn't it?

Cons
- Not really a big deal. It's a pity that there is no more background of the characters, a prequel should do some good to the game.
- You don't really do much. It's more or less a walking simulator.
- After the first chapter, it's not too creepy anymore
- Feels unfinished. I mean, After the third chapter, I wonder what would happen with the characters. Sure, there is the fourth, multiplayer chapter, but I don't think it's the answer.

Value: Buy it if you got interested, but don't spend much. A dollar should be the most.

28480804.review:
I got this game as a gift that was to an extent a joke.

That being said, for what it is, for what was shown of it, I got pretty much what I expected. Is it worth 99 cents? Maybe not, but I didn't have to pay for it, so here are some pros and cons.

Pros
-Trigger system works, basic though it may be.
-If you're like me and don't handle any form of horror well, then a few of the jump scares might get you.
-The graphics shouldn't be a drag on your computer. If they are, then the problem is with you and your potato computer. By themselves, the graphics aren't anything to praise, but they're not the worst. They won't age well, though.
-Simple gameplay (easy to learn).

Cons
-Simple storyline to say the least. If it was actually expanded on in any detail, I might be more forgiving to the game overall.
-Linear gameplay (not always bad, obviously, but in this case it is a detriment).
-Other than jumpscares and horror cliches, not too much originality in the horror department, what "horror" there is.
-Simple gameplay (very simple).

So would I recommend this game to be bought for personal use? Not unless it's on sale, and at that point it's so cheap that the choice to buy it or not will make a miniscule impact on your wallet at best. If you're getting it to see how your friends react to it as a gift, then that's completely up to you.

Was this game worth writing this lengthy review for? Most people would probably say no, but I try to review all the games I play.

26616365.review:
Brace yourselves...I'm going to leave one of the few positive reviews for this game.

First, let's get over the points that everyone makes. Yes, it's very short. Yes, the graphics are boxy and not very detailed. Yes, the voice acting is abysmal.

BUT...I think there's some potential here. The developers may have made it some time ago with just the two of them...but with the right crew behind it there could be something here. Flesh out the stories a bit and make it longer...get some decent voice actors.....redo the maps so there's more background detail...remove the "??????" clouds so players don't KNOW to expect an 'event'....it could be pretty good.

It does rely mostly on jump scares - the bad voice acting really doesn't help create the unsettling atmosphere they were going for....but surprisingly the low-res graphics don't detract. After all, Afraid Of Monsters isn't exactly up there with Bioshock as far as looks go....

It's very cheap, and you can even wait for a sale...but please don't just pass it up because the developers had to make do with what they could get.

Although....there really isn't any excuse for the textures on the police car being back to front :D

I'd like to see a remake, please?

*Sniff* Oh *Sniff* OH! It smells like someone left a group of OC's here. But jokes aside, This game is bad even for mobile game standards and I shall go into detail as to why in the upcoming paragraph.


      I would like to start off with a disclaimer: I don't claim that I could do better, but I have been gaming for a number of years so I am confident in my abilities to distinguish good from bad, this game is bad.

     The graphics are terrible, coming from someone that frequents Abe's Oddysee, that's kinda crazy.

      Then there's the gameplay, you basically walk around clicking "!!!" until something happens and that continues for the whole game, so there isn't really any gameplay to speak of.
      
         Of course I gotta talk about the story. The game is spread out across 3 or 4 levels with a different protagonist for each. It's pretty forgettable in terms of quality. Hence why I'm not going to go into detail about it.
         
         Okay, enough procrastination, time to talk horror. The few jump scares/events that do occur are not scary at all, they consist of shadow people and the occasional loud noise. I don't feel any atmosphere, the music kinda sucks in atmosphere's respect.

         I think that's it. I applaud the devs for their effort but I personally think it could have been better. It has a fair amount of potential that I don't think it's going to reach. 23807219.review:
Lo único bueno que puedo decir es que por su precio, si lo compras con una buena oferta podrás vender los cromos y te saldrá prácticamente pagado (puede que incluso ganes unos céntimos).

No entraré a analizar sus gráficos (que son espantosos) porque, después de todo, se trata de un juego indie. Tampoco puedo hablar de la experiencia de realidad virtual, pues no dispongo de dicho dispositivo, por lo que únicamente he probado la versión normal del juego. Y es mala, mala a dolor.

Lo primero que vino a mi memoria fue que la experiencia era similar a la del juego de Slender: 8 pages. Pero pasados dos segundos quedó patente mi error: delante de mí, flotando en medio del aire, había tres signos de interrogación enormes que, presumiblemente, eran mi primer objetivo. Y no, no se trata de un tutorial para familiarizarse con controles: el juego consiste COMPLETAMENTE en buscar esos símbolos por el nivel y acercarse a ellos para ir recolectando fragmentos de conversación del protagonista. Donde Slender triunfaba al dejarte perdido en un bosque, sin saber hacia dónde ir o qué hacer y provocándote una sensación de inseguridad y de desorientación, este juego lo destroza completamente, con un elemento que rompe totalmente la inmersión y que además convierte en la experiencia en una simple ruta guiada.

He dicho que cada vez que llegas a tocar uno de esos conjuntos de signos interrogativos aparece una sección de diálogo, lo que podría llevar a pensar que, después de todo, lo principal del juego radica en su historia, y no en su inmersión. Nada más lejos de la realidad: los fragmentos de texto son insulsos, simplones y, además, innecesarios. Lo primero que iba a criticar de este juego, antes siquiera de probarlo, era que estuviera traducido a varios idiomas como italiano o francés y no lo estuviera al español. Después de probarlo, puedo decir que casi es una ventaja que no lo esté. Además, estos pequeños textos banales están acompañados de un dibujo del protagonista, muy mal realizado y siempre el mismo, y de una voz en japonés, supuestamente. Ah, dios mío, las voces...

Lo primero que uno esperaría es que la voz dijera lo mismo que está escrito en el texto. Esa era mi impresión las primeras veces, pero resulta que no. Se trata de varias listas de texto leídas y que se repiten sin cesar. Pero el punto fuerte es, sin duda, la expresividad de esta voz: imaginad a un actor fracasado de tercera, con la mayor resaca de su vida, leyendo en vox alta el texto sin un ápice de entusiasmo. Pues ese discurso sería digno de un premio de doblaje comparado con la monótona voz que vas a escuchar repetirse de forma continua durante todo el juego. ¡Ah, eso es lo bueno! Que por lo menos este horror es increíblemente corto: solamente tres misiones, las dos primeras realizables en menos de 5 minutos y una tercera que se termina en 6 o 7 como mucho. Pero no os creáis, que el creador de esta abominación ha pensado en todo, y esos apenas 15 minutos de juego se os harán tan eternos como si llevárais varias horas jugado. ¿Cómo? Pues hablemos del control...

Simple y sencillo: cuatro botones para moverte hacia adelante, hacia atrás y a los lados. El movimiento del ratón para controlar la vista, y el botón E para pasar los insufribles pero gracias a dios cortos textos de diálogo (más bien monólogo). Nuestro personaje se mueve con la gracilidad de un octogenario con artritis, reúma y gota crónica: creo que es el movimiento más lento que he visto en ningún videojuego, en ocasiones quedándote parado da la impresión de que vas más deprisa que si caminas. Para los impacientes, el botón Q te permite correr... bueno, correr... en realidad, lo que te permite es hacer un pequeño sprint durante 1 segundo o menos, a una velocidad, como mucho, del doble de tu paso normal, lo que sigue siendo más lento que el paso relajado de una tortuga. Encima, cada vez que pulses el botón Q, lo que será de forma continua cada 2 segundos (porque además entre Q y Q tienes un tiempo de espera antes de poder darte semejante carrera), se escucha el sonido del chirrido estridente de dos tuercas oxidadas tratando de moverse (sin duda debe de tratarse del hierro en la cadera de nuestro querido y anciano protagonista). Así que lo que más vas a escuchar son chirridos continuos y diálogos repetidos de nuestro soso japonés.

Por suerte el resto de sonidos del juego están a la altura del resto del producto. El apartado sonoro está lleno de sonidos toscos, chirriantes, colocados casi al azar y que aparecen de golpe sin ninguna introducción y se cortan con la misma intensidad tonal con la que aparecieron. Un niño de 5 años soplando una trompeta con la misma nota durante una hora resultaría más relajante que la música de este juego. Se supone que la brusquedad de estos sonidos tiene como cometido el asustar al jugador, uniendo sus esfuerzos a la aparición de dos o tres sombras que se mueven de un lado a otro o de maniquíes que cambian de lugar o de posición de repente. Ni que decir tiene que la combinación fracasa estrepitosamente.

En definitiva, si tienes 15 minutos y necesitas algo que te ponga de mal humor, éste es tu juego. Malo, feo y... bueno, baato sí que es. Aunque claro, si comparamos el precio a su calidad, podemos estar ante uno de los juegos más caros de la historia. ¡Ah, sí, que el juego tiene multijugador! Claro que, como no había nadie con quien jugar, no lo puedo evaluar...

23492351.review:
5/10

Note: for the purpose of this review, I didn't play the game with a VR set.

The TL;DR version of this review is: it's a bad game, but it has its own charm.

I cannot say it's not a bad game, because it is. The graphics are terrible, the voice acting is abysmal and there are major flaws in the game - right in the first chapter, you can actually "find" one of the shadows that comes as part of one of the jump scares, as it's not removed from the game after the scare moment is gone. If you walk outside, you can find it just sitting there.

It also doesn't help that the last chapter of the game tries to be a multiplayer mode. You'd think that last chapter would have more story that would fill in the blanks of the first three chapters, but nope - it's just a large level that attempts to pit players against each other, as you can set up scare traps and follow other players' footsteps while looking for clues at the same time. It's not actually a bad idea. The problem is... No one is playing it. There were two servers available, both of which were empty.

It also doesn't help that the game is incredibly short (you can finish it in less than an hour, possibly less than half an hour), has a 3-stars score system that makes no sense (I completed chapter 2 as quickly as possible while completing all events and still got only 2 stars) and has a story that is still left filled with questions once you've played all chapters.

So, why do I recommend the game despite all these flaws?

As bad as the game might be, it has its own charm, in a way. It's actually decently scary, even if mostly all scare events are predictable, and the game leaves no breathing space - unless you stop playing, it's one jump scare right after the other. And I'd be willing to bet that the game is actually a lot scarier if you're playing it with a VR set.

For the ridiculously low price it has, I'd recommend it as a one time experience. if you're a fan of horror games. Don't get me wrong, it IS a bad game. But you might find some redeeming value nonetheless.

18654940.review:
What the fuck is this? This isn't really a horror game, this is more of a walking simulator, because nothing really kills you (Except water).

If you are scared of loud noises every 10 seconds, and shadows that pop out of nowhere, yet are perfectly harmless, I guess this is right up your alley.

The controls are terrible, you move at a snail's pace, the mouse doesn't disappear until you click something, and you've got this short little "sprint" that lasts less than a second if you press Q. You need to press it each 2 seconds or so, and it's quite annoying, because it gives you think that you are going faster. (You are, but it's still painfully slow).

The music is meh, the ambient sounds are half creepy, yet they get old rather fast. The voice "acting" is ATROCIOUS and gets old in less than a minute. It's the same stuff in japanese over and over and over. The first character sound like it was voices with microsoft Sam or something like that. 

The art style is unremarkable, it's just fucking manga, and it isn't even that good.

Graphics? Typical unpolished low quality unity graphics with endless pitch black darkness in front of you.

Art? Meh.

Sound? Terrible.

Controls? Fucking terrible.

Plot? As I said, it's a walking simulator, but even still, the plot doesn't even make any sense. It's not even cliche, it's just something that a 10 year old could come up with.

Pros? Well, there are cards, if you are into that. And it's short, so your torture is nice, short and sweet. 

Oh, and there's multiplayer, but I don't know if it's broken or not. Good luck finding somebody to play this game with. I got it as a gift and I feel insulted, because I think I killed a few of my brain cells.

18339284.review:
Yech. While not an enjoyable game, it certainly has the atmosphere down pat!
I dunno, maybe I am just the type to be easily scared?

All the while I was playing this, I couldn't tell if I was in immenent danger for making the wrong decisions (like Slenderman, for example) or if the game was a haunted house experience. The fact that it wasn't clear was annoying, but at the same time, not knowing just added to the tension.

The voice acting is a little too loud and lacks any emotion at all, relating to the character portraits. If I were to change something about the game, it would probably be just the voice acting, which would be better if it was at least recorded with a better microphone.

.Music - A little repetitive. Definitely spooky - 7/10
.Sounds - Convincing, scary and well timed - 10/10
.Art - Somewhat limited character portraits. Decent character art style. 3d art is pretty standard for a home made Unity game. Well furnished environments. - 9/10
.Story and Progression - Unconvincing and repetitive. Doesn't seem to be the focal point. - 5/10 (taking into consideration that it isn't focal)
.Voice acting - Terrible. Down right terrible. All lines in the game are voiced, but it is way too loud and emotionless. The recording quality is terrible. - 2/10 (points for fully voiced)

I didn't get to experience the Occulus Rift features because I don't own the hardware. No doubt I would have shat myself if I had tried playing like that.

Reveiw as of completing the first chapter only. 14/15 events triggered. (I mised the tree on the other side of the wall).
I give the first chapter a 7/10 for overall experience. (not quite the same as the average of the other scores).

Not a remarkable game, but the price you pay for it won't leave a sting in your pocket. You'd buy a candy bar for as much, and enjoy it for just as long.

17736907.review:
Disillusions is so incomprehensibly hokey, so bizarrely cheesy that, as a hardcore horror movie fan, I want to love it. I really do. But this is a walking simulator and a bad one at that. 
The controls go a long way towards that conclusion. With WASD unavailable for movement, you're forced to use the arrow keys to navigate and the mouse to turn which wouldn't be a major problem if you didn't also have to use E and Q. Do me a favour, pop one hand on your arrow keys then one on your mouse. Now try and reach either E or Q. What's even worse is that Q is sprint, rendering it effectively useless unless you can jog on the spot. Which you can't.
The plot is a mess, the characters are irritating and the multiplayer is one of the most baffling looking things you will lay eyes upon in some time. Maybe the only decent thing I can say about it is that for £0.79, you can experience the unintentional hilarity of the Hat Mannequin Death House, where limbless wooden horrors bob for apples, kick trash bags around and throw hammers at you with their mouths.

17494729.review:
So, another day, another poor horror game.
Why the hell am I doing this to myself. I must have some masochism disorder. Hmm.

Ok, what is wrong with this one?
Does the cheap price can excuse everything?
Does a game made by "one man in his attic and his girlfriend in their spare time" should explain the result here?
I say no. SORRY, NO. These are not excuses goddammit.

-Level design is bad, it is way too harsh: it looks like someone cut pieces of planes, polygons & models with an axe before assembling them. They are too empty too.
-Textures are horrible. Seriously, that's not the first time there is this problem in this kind of games! STOP using this much bump mapping!! STOP, THIS IS REALLY DISGUSTING!!! Also, not enough/not any specular on various textures. They don't look natural and are too dark.
-Cheap jumpscares everywhere with moving shadows and mannequins. How original. How unscary.
-Too much forced camera movements. You can do this sometimes to make the player see something that happens but don't abuse of it, here this is too much.
-Multiplayer mode is not really funny to play at all so it's disappointing.
-Google translated game. I tried French, saw the massacre, instantly switched to English. If you want someone to update/correct this for free PM me dev.

On the other hand,

-Story was not super innovative... at least there was an attempt, ok. End was predictable and a little cliché but that was not a problem for me. Too short though.
-Anime character sprites are not so bad but they could use more details (like at least some shadows).
-The jumpscares were too cheap and repetitive like I said BESIDES two events that were actually not too bad, I'm talking about [spoiler]the walls that disolve at the end of chapter 2, reminded me of Silent Hill 3, plus the final event of chapter 3, with the books flying around and so on[/spoiler].
-Text describing various things, events... maybe a little too much but I liked the idea.

I can't really recommend this game, even at this low price. This should be free.
This project lacks of details and attention, especially those pretty crappy textures. I'm sorry but NO, this is a REAL problem that happens too often. It is not hard to make nice looking textures damn, or at least ones which have the right amount of bump, spec, illumination, etc..

TL;DR: even with a huge discount I can't recommend it. Principles. It is not polished, jumpscares are too cheap. I don't wanna seem mean but it really, really needs to be improved a lot, there are too many failures.

14083602.review:
This is mostly a review for the developer(s), to help them improve upon either this game or the next one.

---

I don't really like jumpscares or horror games made with the Unity tool, but I do like anime style art and visual novels, so I thought I'd give this one a go seeing as it costs oh so very little.

Some of the jumpscares were a little off. For example: [spoiler]the hammer flew at me when I wasn't in front of the window, but to the side of it. Because I couldn't see the hammer, I wasn't startled at all.[/spoiler]
Even though the story is very short, the jumpscares were fairly repetitive. For example: [spoiler]the mannequins move. All of them! After the first two I got the drill and they didn't startle me at all after that.[/spoiler]
...I do have to admit I played this game during the day and without headphones, because I scare very easily. (But that doesn't mean none of the jumpscares got me! It's just, as soon as I was able to predict them, they didn't scare me anymore.)

The voice acting would've been a nice touch, if the acting wasn't so bad. "Ah. It's a ghost." --> that didn't sound like the character was scared at all. It sounds like someone's just speaking the words from the page, without visualising an actual scary scene. (Were the voice actors chosen simply because they could speak Japanese? I'm not sure if this game was originally Japanese or not, but I'm guessing it wasn't.) Anyway, voice acting is nice and all, but without professional actors it just deducts from the whole experience. 
In this case I'd say: maybe give the player the option to turn the voices off. Cause every time they started talking (out loud, I mean) the creepy atmosphere disappeared.

After having started the third chapter I wondered why the first two chapters weren't added together to make one chapter. That's because there is suddenly a different main character for the last chapter. I mean, I understand that there's three chapters because of the three locations, but I still think it would've been better to have two chapters with two different protagonists. What do you think?

I really didn't expect the twist at the end of the second chapter, because I was thinking we'd be following DiS for the duration of the three chapters and it's the kind of twist you'd expect at the end of all things. 
The twist at the end of the third chapter, on the other hand, was not unexpected AT ALL. The story kept hinting at [spoiler]Sui's mental disorder[/spoiler] in a not-so-subtle way - like [spoiler]when she looks at the café and goes like "those people deserved it, teehee"[/spoiler] - kind of like the mannequins I was talking about earlier (in the second spoiler).

The anime art style was quite nice, I really liked it! 
I just didn't understand Sui's alternate costume: it's not in the game proper, only in the options menu, but just its being there tells the player a lot about Sui. [spoiler]For me, it spoiled the twist that, gasp, omg, Sui was the murderer! There's gotta be something wrong with anyone who dresses like that. ;)[/spoiler]
I'm not sure about the virtual environment, uh, like, I mean the backgrounds and mannequins and stuff: it didn't look very special to me, just another Unity horror game, I guess.

I didn't make use of the VR support, because I don't have an Oculus Rift. (VR horror games just creep me out way too much!)

I'm giving the review a thumbs up because I intend to play it again sometime. It's short enough for that. Maybe I'll try to beat the high score.

---

All in all I didn't think it was a bad game [i]per se[/i], but I do think it would've been better if this game were free. 
I'm not trying to rob you of your income here, but it seems like this game was more of an experiment than a full-fledged, actual, finished game. There were too many clichés (storywise) and not enough actual horror/jumpscares (see mannequins and hammer mentioned earlier).
I don't think you deserve the tone in which some people have reviewed this game, I really don't. But that's not to say I disagree with some of the points they've made.

Hope this helps! Good luck on your next project!
